title: The Zinke, Tranel (and Lamb) show
excerpt: Ryan Zinke and Monica Tranel are the two main contenders for Montana’s new western U.S. House district. The presence of Libertarian John Lamb and Zinke’s long, variable record in government could make things complicated.

title: Ann Bukacek and John Repke: Two views vie for one seat on the PSC
excerpt: Retired executive John Repke hopes to be the first Democratic PSC commissioner in over a decade. Republican Ann Bukacek’s conservative platform has helped launch the Flathead Valley physician into the regulatory arena. On Nov. 8 voters will pick one to serve on the state’s influential Public Service Commission.

title: Abortion-rights advocates rally support for Gustafson in Montana Supreme Court race
excerpt: With four weeks until Election Day, reproductive rights advocates in Montana and across the country are throwing their weight behind a down-ballot candidate they say is key to maintaining abortion access across much of the Rocky Mountain west: Supreme Court Justice Ingrid Gustafson.

title: Zinke, Tranel debate abortion, affordability and their personal histories
excerpt: The candidates for Montana’s Western U.S. House seat have now faced off in the public forum three times, tangling over abortion and the economy and dissecting each other’s attack lines as Nov. 8 approaches.

title: The divergent energy visions of Montana’s U.S. House candidates
excerpt: U.S. House candidates Ryan Zinke and Monica Tranel have both worked on energy issues on public and private payrolls. Zinke, a Republican, underscores the importance of “American energy independence” and emphasizes the role of fossil fuels in that vision. Tranel, a Democrat, prioritizes a transition to clean energy that “has to start quickly and accelerate.”

title: Longtime Butte Democrat Art Noonan dead at 70
excerpt: Art Noonan, one-time executive director of the Montana Democratic Party and member of an influential old guard of Irish-American Butte lawmakers, has died.

title: Tschida, Curdy face off in race for key state Senate seat
excerpt: Diane Sands’ term-limited departure leaves an open path for either party to take Senate District 49 in an election year when Democrats hope to hold as much ground as possible against a surging Montana GOP that needs only two more seats to achieve a bicameral legislative supermajority. The district is at the center of both ambitions, and in the background are major policy debates around abortion, housing affordability and the economy.

title: Eastern district U.S. House candidates on the issues
excerpt: Here’s what the general election candidates for Montana’s eastern district house seat told us when we put an issue-focused questionnaire to them during the spring primary. Compare their answers — and tell us what more you want to know.

title: Western district U.S. House candidates on the issues
excerpt: Here’s what the general election candidates for Montana’s western district house seat told us when we put an issue-focused questionnaire to them during the spring primary. Compare their answers — and tell us what more you want to know.

title: Unions buck expectations with endorsement of independent financial manager Gary Buchanan in eastern district
excerpt: Montana’s largest labor union and its overarching federation have announced their endorsement of an independent financial advisor over a Democratic former union member in Montana’s eastern district U.S. House race.

title: Federal report: Zinke violated ‘duty of candor’
excerpt: A federal ethics probe has concluded that former Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke, who is running to represent Montana’s western district in the U.S. House, misled an internal ethics watchdog.

title: Tranel, Zinke, and Lamb spar over abortion, climate and energy
excerpt: The three candidates for Montana’s newly created western congressional district squared off in person for the first time at a candidate forum in Missoula, landing glancing blows and setting the stage for a race that will elevate Montana issues to the national stage and localize national political dynamics as the major parties vie for control of the U.S. House of Representatives.

title: Contested race in SD 39 puts state hospital, Republican supermajority in focus
excerpt: The unexpected death in May of state Sen. Mark Sweeney, D-Philipsburg, has created an open seat and contested race to fill out the two-year remainder of the late lawmaker’s term in a historically Democratic district that presents an appealing target for state Republicans this cycle.

title: Recounts results confirm Bukacek won utility board GOP primary
excerpt: Ballot recounts conducted in four counties, which concluded Monday, confirm that Flathead Valley internal medicine doctor Ann “Annie” Bukacek has won the Republican primary for a seat on the five-member board that regulates the state’s monopoly utility power, water, garbage and telecommunications companies. She defeated Rep. Derek Skees and two other challengers in the tight race.

title: Bukacek presumptive winner of Republican PSC primary
excerpt: The latest count for the District 5 Public Service Commission GOP primary puts Flathead Valley physician Ann “Annie” Bukacek 87 votes ahead of termed-out state legislator Derek Skees. Though Bukacek’s lead has grown by 13 votes since the June 8 count, the margin is still tight enough — within half of 1% — that the secretary of state has it flagged as being one of just three primary races that could be eligible for a recount. Skees hasn’t said if he’ll pursue a recount.

title: Ryan Zinke narrowly wins Western district Republican primary
excerpt: Former congressman and Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke narrowly won the Republican primary on Thursday in the inaugural race to represent Montana’s Western congressional district. He will face off against Democrat Monica Tranel on the November ballot.

title: Gustafson and Brown advancing over McMahon in Montana Supreme Court primary
excerpt: Montana Supreme Court Justice Ingrid Gustafson and Public Service Commission Chair James Brown have emerged as the top two vote-getters in the non-partisan primary election for the high court’s second seat, setting up a general election clash at a time of high political visibility for the court.

title: Rosendale, Ronning emerge from eastern Montana U.S. House primary
excerpt: Primary victors Republican Matt Rosendale and Democrat Penny Ronning and independent Gary Buchanan will compete in the November general election. Libertarian Sam Rankin also led his party primary late Tuesday.

title: Monica Tranel wins Democratic primary for U.S. House in western district
excerpt: As of late Tuesday night, the Republican primary race between Ryan Zinke and Al Olszewski was too close to call. On the Democratic side, Monica Tranel will advance to the general election with a decisive win.

title: Montana congressional candidates make final primary push
excerpt: Candidates vying for Montana’s two congressional districts are in the final sprint of their primary campaigns leading up to the June 7 election. In the Western district, five Republicans and three Democrats are jockeying to represent their party on the November ballot. One Libertarian candidate is running unopposed. In the Eastern district, four Republicans, including incumbent Rep. Matt Rosendale, are competing to represent their party alongside three Democratic candidates and three Libertarians.

title: Buchanan likely has signatures needed for independent U.S. House bid
excerpt: Preliminary figures from the Montana secretary of state indicate the candidate has gathered 4,500 more signatures than he needs to qualify for the November ballot to represent Montana’s eastern U.S. House district.

title: Meet the PSC candidates who want to regulate your rates
excerpt: Originally formed in 1907 to oversee railroad operations, the five-member Public Service Commission regulates monopolies in the power, natural gas, water, telecommunications and garbage collection industries. This year’s PSC race has drawn an eclectic mix of candidates vying for two open seats on the commission — among the highest-paid positions in state government — and each candidate is pitching a different understanding of the commission’s role.

title: Republican support colors Montana Supreme Court race
excerpt: In his campaign for the Montana Supreme Court seat currently held by Justice Ingrid Gustafson, who is seeking re-election, attorney James Brown is receiving the race’s most overtly partisan support from a long list of elected Republicans. This month, Brown referenced Gov. Greg Gianforte’s support of his candidacy when he told attendees at a candidate event in Butte that the governor had asked him to consider entering the race.

title: In Eastern district U.S. House race, it’s Rosendale versus the idealists
excerpt: Republican incumbent Matt Rosendale is the clear favorite as he seeks re-election to Congress in Montana’s newly drawn Eastern district. That hasn’t stopped a crew of motivated challengers from trying to convince voters to support a more moderate vision of Montana politics.

title: Who holds the keys to Montana’s Western congressional seat?
excerpt: The nine candidates in Montana’s new Western congressional district — a jagged ‘C’ encompassing Glacier County, Kalispell, Missoula, the Bitterroot Valley, Butte and Gallatin County — are as ideologically varied as the population they seek to represent. Which candidate can unlock House District 1’s political identity?

title: U.S. House candidate Sweeney will remain on ballot despite recent death
excerpt: Mark Sweeney, a Democrat running in Montana’s eastern congressional district, died unexpectedly over the weekend. But voters will still see his name on the June 7 primary ballot. What happens if he wins?

title: Bipartisan old guard lines up behind independent U.S. House candidate
excerpt: Businessman Gary Buchanan of Billings, challenging Rep. Matt Rosendale for Montana’s eastern congressional district U.S. House seat, touts support from political figures who were among the most prominent Montana Republicans and Democrats in the 1990s and 2000s.

title: The politics driving the Montana Supreme Court races
excerpt: Members of the state’s highest court have spent much of the last year defending their branch of government while prominent Republican officials publicly challenge the judiciary and scrutinize its operations. Now, some of those same Republican officials have thrown their weight behind a particular candidate and levied public smears against both incumbents, inserting overtly partisan messaging into traditionally nonpartisan races.

title: Five candidates in the race for two Montana Supreme Court seats
excerpt: The statewide, nonpartisan Supreme Court races may turn out to be among the highest profile of any on the ballot this year, with incumbent Justice Ingrid Gustafson’s three-way primary drawing particular attention. Here are the candidates and their backgrounds.

title: Seven Republicans, two Democrats running for two Public Service Commission seats
excerpt: Seven Republicans and two Democrats have filed to campaign for the two seats coming open on Montana’s Public Service Commission, the five-member body that regulates investor-owned utility companies with captive customer bases. Here’s how the races are shaping up against a new commission district map and the PSC’s recent scandals.

title: Congressional races up and running
excerpt: Candidates running for seats in the U.S. House of Representatives have filed their requisite paperwork as of 5 p.m. Monday, bringing the tally of active candidates up to nine Republicans, six Democrats, four Libertarians and one Independent.
